author: Al Landes
title: China Orders Its Tech Companies To Boycott Nvidia - NewsBreak
text: Your enterprise IT team just got a new headache. Those Nvidia H20 chips you’ve been evaluating for your AI projects? Chinese regulators now claim they’re packed with backdoors and security vulnerabilities—turning routine procurement decisions into geopolitical chess moves reminiscent of other tech scandals . The controversy erupted when China’s Cyberspace Administration summoned Nvidia officials in July , demanding explanations about alleged “remote shutdown” capabilities in the H20 chip line. State media outlets, led by the influential Yuyuan Tantian account, launched a coordinated campaign urging Chinese companies to boycott the chips entirely. Even the People’s Daily joined the chorus, demanding Nvidia provide “convincing evidence” that their hardware isn’t compromised. Chinese officials have made serious accusations, but the evidence remains conspicuously absent. State media launched a coordinated offensive across Chinese publications, making several key claims: The performance context matters here. The H20 delivers only 15% of Nvidia’s flagship H100 capability due to U.S. export restrictions—hardly the cutting-edge threat Beijing portrays. Several Chinese tech companies have already announced reduced H20 orders, pivoting toward domestic alternatives like Huawei’s offerings amid broader AI training controversies . Nvidia’s response has been categorical: “There are no backdoors in the H20,” company representatives stated, emphasizing the chip wasn’t designed for military or government infrastructure. The company stressed its compliance with both U.S. and Chinese regulatory requirements. Industry analysts suggest this resembles previous tech boycott playbooks more than legitimate security discoveries. “Despite performance restrictions, the H20 remains a world-class product relative to Chinese competitors,” one semiconductor expert noted, highlighting the political timing of these allegations. The H20’s troubled journey reflects broader U.S.-China decoupling . Originally banned by the Trump administration in April 2025 , export restrictions were lifted just three months later as part of ongoing trade negotiations—only for Chinese authorities to now question the very chips they previously sought. For enterprise buyers, this creates an impossible calculus: The real question isn’t whether these chips contain backdoors—it’s whether tech procurement decisions will ever again be purely technical in our fractured digital world.
